thread.title: Cory Wells dead: Three Dog Night singer dies at 74 in Western New York
thread.title_full: Cory Wells dead: Three Dog Night singer dies at 74 in Western New York | syracuse.com

author: Geoff Herbert | gherbert@syracuse.com
title: Cory Wells dead: Three Dog Night singer dies at 74 in Western New York
text:
Three Dog Night singer Cory Wells is dead at 74, the band announced Wednesday.
The vocalist and co-founding member of the '70s rock group "died unexpectedly" on Tuesday, Oct. 20, at his Western New York home in Dunkirk, near Fredonia.
"It is with deep sadness and disbelief that I must report the passing of Cory Wells, my beloved band mate for over 45 years," his bandmate Danny Hutton said. "Cory was an incredible singer -- a great performer, he could sing anything. Cory was like a brother in so many ways. We had been together since 1965 and I am in shock at this sudden loss."
According to Billboard , Wells shared lead vocal duties with Hutton and Chuck Negron. The band had 21 top 40 hits and hit No. 1 with three songs: "Joy to the World," "Mama Told Me (Not to Come)" and "Black and White."
Wells, born Emil Lewandowski in Buffalo in 1941, joined the U.S. Air Force after high school and formed a band called The Del-Vikings. According to the Buffalo News , he returned home after his service and played with bands like the Vibratos, the Enemys, the Fidelitones and the Satellites.
According to a press release, he met Hutton in L.A. in the mid 1960s, and they set out to form a group with three lead singers. Wells never left, performing with Three Dog Night for more than 50 years until he had to drop out of the band last month due to severe back pains.
Fellow original Three Dog Night member Jimmy Greenspoon died at 67 in March from cancer.
Wells is survived by Mary, his wife of 50 years, his daughters Coryann and Dawn Marie, and five grandchildren.
I will miss you❤️ pic.twitter.com/PWR4JZUZNG
— Chuck Negron (@ChuckNegron) October 21, 2015
